contextId.occurrenceNote: James is using rhetorical questions to teach and possibly scold his readers. Alternate translation: "you are making judgments among yourselves and becoming judges with evil thoughts." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οὐ διεκρίθητε ἐν ἑαυτοῖς, καὶ ἐγένεσθε κριταὶ διαλογισμῶν πονηρῶν
contextId.glQuote: are you not judging among yourselves? Have you not become judges with evil thoughts?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here James uses a rhetorical question to teach his readers not to show favoritism. It can be made a statement. Alternate translation: "God has chosen ... love him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οὐχ ὁ Θεὸς ἐξελέξατο τοὺς πτωχοὺς τῷ κόσμῳ, πλουσίους ἐν πίστει, καὶ κληρονόμους τῆς βασιλείας ἧς ἐπηγγείλατο τοῖς ἀγαπῶσιν αὐτόν
contextId.glQuote: did not God choose ... love him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here James uses a rhetorical question to correct his readers. Alternate translation: "It is rich people who oppress you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj ]])
contextId.quote: οὐχ οἱ πλούσιοι καταδυναστεύουσιν ὑμῶν?
contextId.glQuote: Is it not the rich who oppress you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here James uses a rhetorical question to correct his readers. It can be made a statement. Alternate translation: "The rich people are the ones ... to court." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: αὐτοὶ ἕλκουσιν ὑμᾶς εἰς κριτήρια
contextId.glQuote: Are they not the ones ... to court?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here James uses a rhetorical question to correct and teach his readers. It can be made a statement. Alternate translation: "The rich people insult ... have been called." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οὐκ αὐτοὶ βλασφημοῦσιν τὸ καλὸν ὄνομα τὸ ἐπικληθὲν ἐφ’ ὑμᾶς
contextId.glQuote: Do they not insult ... have been called?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James is using a rhetorical question to teach his audience. Alternate translation: "It is no good at all, fellow believers, if someone says he has faith, but he has no works." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: τί τὸ ὄφελος, ἀδελφοί μου, ἐὰν πίστιν λέγῃ τις, ἔχειν ἔργα, δὲ μὴ ἔχῃ
contextId.glQuote: What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith, but he has no works?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James is using a rhetorical question to teach his audience. This can be restated to remove the abstract noun "faith." Alternate translation: "That faith cannot save him." or "If a person does not do what God commands, then just saying he believes in God will not save him." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns ]])
contextId.quote: μὴ δύναται ἡ πίστις σῶσαι αὐτόν?
contextId.glQuote: Can that faith save him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses a rhetorical question to teach his audience. Alternate translation: "that is not good." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: τί τὸ ὄφελος?
contextId.glQuote: what good is that?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to introduce the next part of his teaching. Alternate translation: "Listen to me, foolish man, and I will show that faith without works is useless." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: θέλεις δὲ γνῶναι, ὦ ἄνθρωπε κενέ, ὅτι ἡ πίστις χωρὶς τῶν ἔργων ἀργή ἐστιν?
contextId.glQuote: Do you want to know, foolish man, that faith without works is useless?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used to rebut the foolish man's arguments from [James 2:18](../02/18.md), who refuses to believe that faith and works go together. Alternate translation: "Abraham our father was certainly justified ... on the altar." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: Ἀβραὰμ ὁ πατὴρ ἡμῶν οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων ἐδικαιώθη, ἀνενέγκας Ἰσαὰκ τὸν υἱὸν αὐτοῦ ἐπὶ τὸ θυσιαστήριον?
contextId.glQuote: Was not Abraham our father justified ... on the altar?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James is using this rhetorical question to instruct his audience. Alternate translation: "it was what Rahab the prostitute did that justified her ... another road." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive ]])
contextId.quote: Ῥαὰβ ἡ πόρνη οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων ἐδικαιώθη, ὑποδεξαμένη τοὺς ἀγγέλους, καὶ ἑτέρᾳ ὁδῷ ἐκβαλοῦσα
contextId.glQuote: was not Rahab the prostitute justified by works ... another road?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses a rhetorical question to remind believers about what happens in nature. This can be expressed as a sentence. Alternate translation: "You know that a spring does not pour out both sweet water and bitter water." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: μήτι ἡ πηγὴ ἐκ τῆς αὐτῆς ὀπῆς βρύει τὸ γλυκὺ καὶ τὸ πικρόν
contextId.glQuote: Does a spring pour out from its opening both sweet and bitter water?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses another rhetorical question to remind the believers about what happens in nature. Alternate translation: "Brothers, you know that a fig tree cannot grow olives." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: μὴ δύναται, ἀδελφοί μου, συκῆ ἐλαίας ποιῆσαι
contextId.glQuote: Does a fig tree, my brothers, make olives?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to teach his audience about proper behavior. The words "wise" and "understanding" are similar. Alternate translation: "I will tell you how a wise and understanding person is to act." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet ]])
contextId.quote: τίς σοφὸς καὶ ἐπιστήμων ἐν ὑμῖν?
contextId.glQuote: Who is wise and understanding among you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to rebuke his audience. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "They come from your evil desires for things, desires that fight among your members." or "They come from your desires for evil things, desires that fight among your members." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οὐκ ἐντεῦθεν ἐκ τῶν ἡδονῶν ὑμῶν, τῶν στρατευομένων ἐν τοῖς μέλεσιν ὑμῶν?
contextId.glQuote: Do they not come from your desires that fight among your members?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to teach his audience. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You know ... God!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οὐκ οἴδατε ὅτι ἡ φιλία τοῦ κόσμου, ἔχθρα τοῦ Θεοῦ ἐστιν?
contextId.glQuote: Do you not know ... God?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question James uses to scold his audience. This can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "You are just a human and cannot judge another human." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: σὺ δὲ τίς εἶ ὁ κρίνων τὸν πλησίον?
contextId.glQuote: Who are you, you who judge your neighbor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses these questions to correct his audience and to teach these believers that physical life is not that important. They can be expressed as statements. Alternate translation: "No one knows what will happen tomorrow, and your life does not last very long!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: οἵτινες οὐκ ἐπίστασθε τὸ τῆς αὔριον, ποία ἡ ζωὴ ὑμῶν?
contextId.glQuote: Who knows what will happen tomorrow, and what is your life?

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to cause the readers to reflect on their need. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "If anyone is enduring troubles, he should pray" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: κακοπαθεῖ τις ἐν ὑμῖν? Προσευχέσθω.
contextId.glQuote: Is anyone among you suffering hardship? Let him pray

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to cause the readers to reflect on their blessings. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "If anyone is happy, he should sing songs of praise" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: εὐθυμεῖ τις? Ψαλλέτω.
contextId.glQuote: Is anyone cheerful? Let him sing praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: James uses this question to cause the readers to reflect on their need. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "If anyone is sick, he should call" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion ]])
contextId.quote: ἀσθενεῖ τις ἐν ὑμῖν? προσκαλεσάσθω
contextId.glQuote: Is anyone among you sick? Let him call
